overview.Overview: This experiment explores absorption, capillary action, and color theory in a way that is super fun!

step_1.Step 1: For this activity you will need: paper towels, water, Food coloring, and plastic cups.

step_2.Step 2: You will want to begin with six clear cups or glasses. In the first cup add 5-10 drops of red food coloring. In the third cup add 5-10 drops of yellow food coloring, and in the last cup add 5-10 drops of blue food coloring. Add 1/2 cup of water to the glasses with food coloring and stir until combined.

step_3.Step 3: Leave the two remaining cups empty.

step_4.Step 4: You will need five pieces of extra absorbent paper towel. Fold each piece into strips and then tuck the strips between the glasses. You want to ensure that the paper towels are touching the bottom of the cups, but you don't want your pieces to be too long or to have too much excess paper at the top.

step_5.Step 5: The water from the colorful cups will quickly begin to absorb into the paper towels and then slowly transfer into the empty cups, forming a water rainbow!

step_6.Step 6: To make purple you will want to add a second cup of red water to the end of your cup line as shown in the photo directly above.  This is optional. You could also set this experiment up in a circle, which allows you to make purple while only using one cup of red water!

overview.Overview: Making a lava lamp at home is an easy and fun experiment that the kids are sure to love!

step_1.Step 1: For this experiment you will need: a jar or similar container, Alka Seltzer, baby oil, water, and food coloring

step_2.Step 2: Begin by filling the jar that you are using 3/4 of the way with baby oil, and then add water until the jar is almost full but not all the way filled. Then, add several drops of food coloring.

step_3.Step 3: The food coloring will mix into the water and settle at the bottom of the jar after a few moments. Once the water is settled it is time to make the lava lamp bubble and FIZZ!Have kids break Alka-Seltzer tablets into 3-4 pieces and slowly drop them into the jar.

step_4.Step 4: For a fun twist, make a glow in the dark lava lamp.  You will need two glow sticks and a flashlight. Crack the glow stick, cut off the top, and pour the contents into the water and oil cup. Then add the Alka Seltzer

step_5.Step 5: How does this experiment work? The water and oil do not mix and the oil doesn’t change color because the food coloring is water soluble. The Alka Seltzer reacts with the water to make bubbles of carbon dioxide. The bubbles attach themselves to the blobs of colored water and bring them to the top of the glass. When the bubbles pop the blobs of colored water fall back to the bottom of the glass.

keywords: paper apple fall autumn art craft

overview.Overview: These paper craft apples are not quite edible, but oh, so darling!

step_1.Step 1: For this activity you will need: Uniform strips of paper (cut lengthwise on 8x  paper), ed, yellow, dark green, and light green computer paper (or card stock for a sturdier craft), scissors, single hole punch, 2 brass fasteners per apple

step_2.Step 2: Download and print the paper apple craft template. We printed the templates on colored card stock, but you can also print them on white paper and invite kids to color in their apples and leaves with crayons or markers.

step_3.Step 3: Next, cut out the templates. We used 6 rectangular strips and 1 leaf/apple. If you want your apple to have more solid coverage, simply use more paper strips.

step_4.Step 4: Gently bend the stack of papers and separate each strip to form a sphere.

step_5.Step 5: Carefully tug the paper strips until you are satisfied with their appearance.

overview.Overview: This experiment is a festive precursor to the classic volcano science experiments that are popular at elementary school science fairs. Kids love tinkering and adding more solution to see the bubbles over and over again.

step_1.Step 1: For this experiment you will need: Christmas themed cookie cutters, baking soda, vinegar, liquid water colors, cookie sheet, squirt bottles, and a spoon

step_2.Step 2: Place a giant cookie cutter on a medium-sized cookie sheet. Use a spoon to sprinkle baking soda into the cookie cutter.

step_3.Step 3: Fill several small squirt bottles with vinegar and liquid watercolors. We used red, white, green, and yellow liquid watercolors for the Christmas tree cookie cutter and brown, red, and white for the gingerbread man cookie cutter. If you wish, add 1 drop of clear dish soap to the white vinegar solution for extra fizzing and foaming.

step_4.Step 4: Next, squirt the vinegar into the cookie cutters and watch the design bubble and grow!

step_5.Step 5: How does the baking soda and vinegar experiment work? The baking soda and vinegar experiment is popular because it’s simple, inexpensive, and works over and over again. Baking soda is an alkaline (sodium bicarbonate) and vinegar is an acid. When the two react together, they produce carbon dioxide (the fizzy bubbles in soda or pop, depending on where you’re from). When you combine baking soda and vinegar, there are two reactions. First, there is a double displacement reaction forming sodium acetate and carbonic acid. The second reaction, a decomposition reaction, produces carbon dioxide, also known as the bubbles.  Because the bubbles weigh more than air, they collect and overflow, which is the fun part!

overview.Overview: This Magic Milk Science experiment never gets old! This experiment is fun and easy to set up experiment for the kids.

step_1.Step 1: For this experiment you will need: milk, cotton balls or q-tips, food coloring, and a plate or other shallow container.

step_2.Step 2: Pour milk onto a large glass plate. Towards the center of the milk, pour about 5 drops of desired color of food coloring onto the milk leaving a space between the colors. Try not to let the colors touch, but it’s okay if they do touch. Colors may start to spread out a little and that’s fine, too.

step_3.Step 3: Place a cotton ball into the dish soap. Allow the cotton ball to absorb the dish soap.

step_4.Step 4: Gently place the cotton ball in the center of the colors and let go. The colors should disperse to the sides quickly and start moving around, leaving cool designs around the plate.

step_5.Step 5: If you notice the colors start to slow down with no activity, try pouring a drop of soap into the mixture or repeating the above step. You can also stir around the colors slowly to mix the colors.

step_6.Step 6: How does this experiment work? The soap reacts with both the proteins in the milk and the milk fats themselves. When the soap and proteins interact, the soap makes the proteins change shape, sending them swirling, which in turn makes the colors swirl about. And the soap and fat want to join together in pockets called “micelles” (similar to how soap lifts the grease off your dirty pans!), so that also causes movement. Eventually, everything reaches a balance or “equilibrium”, and the reaction ends. But the milk colors will still move about for a bit as the excess energy works its way out.

overview.Overview: Learn about the weather and why it rains with this fun rainbow experiment for kids!

step_1.Step 1: For this experiment you will need: regular shaving cream (not gel!), food coloring, a jar or other glass cylinder, and water.

step_2.Step 2: Fill your glass about 75% full with water.

step_3.Step 3: Shake the shaving cream well. Spray a layer of shaving cream on top of the water until covered.

step_4.Step 4: Drop two drops of each color of food coloring on top of the shaving cream. Watch the food coloring make it’s way slowly down into the water. Add more food coloring as desired to create more rain!

step_5.Step 5: How does this experiment work? How Does it Work? Just like a cloud the shaving cream slowly takes in the varying colors of rain. As the cloud fills it swells, holding as much inside as it can before reaching it's abundance. It is at this point that the rain begins to fall.

overview.Overview: Grab your coat and head outside for some fun winter science with the kids. You will learn how to make beautiful DIY frozen bubbles with our homemade bubble recipe. It’s such an awesome cold-weather activity for kids of all ages!

step_1.Step 1: For this experiment you will need: An outside temperature between 9 and 12 degrees fahrenheit, bubble solution, (or DIY bubbles with dish soap and glycerin (or light corn syrup), bubble wands or straws, and water.

step_2.Step 2: On a basic level, when you're creating a bubble, you're also interacting with the surface tension of the liquid. So, when it's just water, it's much harder to create a bubble because the water molecules are attracted to other water molecules. Adding soap and corn syrup to the mix weakens the surface tension and makes it much easier to form bubbles.

step_3.Step 3: If you wanted to turn this into an experiment and not an activity for your kids, you could attempt to do this at different temperatures and record the different ways the bubbles freeze or do not freeze. You could also add in a different recipe: liquid soap on its own without water or corn syrup and see how that reacts in the different environments. Questions for them to consider: which formula produces better bubbles? At which temperature do bubbles start freezing in mid-air? Do the sizes of the bubbles differ between the different solutions you're using to make bubbles?

keywords: Winter winter ice balloon active imaginative play

overview.Overview: Have you ever froze Ice Jewels with your kids? They are simple to make and perfect for winter imaginary play!

step_1.Step 1: For this activity you will need: below freezing temperature, balloons, food coloring, and water

step_2.Step 2: To make your own Ice Jewels, drip several drops of food dye or liquid watercolors into balloons, then fill with water. Tie and rinse the balloons, then place them outside (or in a freezer) overnight.

step_3.Step 3: Ice Jewels will keep as long as temperatures stay cold! You can use them to decorate a snow fort or your front yard. Or bury them in the snow and have a treasure hunt!

keywords: craft imaginative play fall autumn creative

overview.Overview: For this activity, you will need: Twelve or more pipe cleaners in brown or black, green felt for leaves, and pom poms of medium and large shape in different shades of green and red.

step_1.Step 1: First, to shape the roots of the tree, bend a pipe cleaner roughly in half. One end should be longer than the other — up to an inch — to vary the length of the branches. Twist the bent end of the folded pipe cleaner tightly and bend it almost to a 90-degree angle. Repeat with all the pipe cleaners.

step_2.Step 2: Next, gather the bent pipe cleaners together and arrange them so that the roots stick out evenly around the base of the tree.  Pinch the pipe cleaners together just above the roots with one hand, then twist the bottom half of the tree trunk together. Once again, make sure it is nice and tight.

step_3.Step 3: Twist some together to make thicker roots. Bend them at different points and angles for a natural appearance. Adjust how far the roots bend away from the trunk until the tree stands up straight.

step_4.Step 4: Spring green craft felt, cut into small leaves: No points for perfection here, just quickly cut out some pieces that were vaguely leaf-shaped.

step_5.Step 5: Arrange the green pom poms (and green felt leaves, if you’re using them) around and behind the tree, and the blue glass gems in front. You might want to place one or two pom poms in the tree to suggest one way a child could use them.

keywords: Christmas Winter craft decoration art creative

overview.Overview: Who doesn't love Christmas trees? These simple, but beautiful trees, will have you saying, Oh tannenbaum!

step_1.Step 1: For this activity you will need: pipe ceaners or chenille sttems in various shades and textures (white, green, metalic, etc.), glitter glue, a thin piece of cardboard (cereal box thickness), small sequins, scissors and tape.

step_2.Step 2: The first thing to do is make a tall, narrow cone from the small piece of cardboard.  Cut it into a triangle with one rounded side. Roll the cardboard into a tight cone and secure well with the tape.

step_3.Step 3: Next, line up a pipe cleaner so that it sticks out a little over the top of the cone.  Pinch the cone and the end of the pipe cleaner and hold it with one hand.  With your other hand, tightly wrap the pipe cleaner around the cone, keeping it as perpendicular as possible so the finished tree can stand up straight.  Make sure to keep wrapping until you have curled the end of the pipe cleaner around the cone.

step_4.Step 4: Ease the pipe cleaner off the cone.  Twist the very top of the tree a little to finish it off. Then tuck the end of the pipe cleaner up inside the tree so it can sit flat.  After that, bend and adjust the tree until it stands up straight and you like the way it looks.

step_5.Step 5: To add the ornaments, I threaded them onto a 3mm white pipe cleaner (the holes in my beads were too small for the 6mm pipe cleaners), then wrapped that with an iridescent white pipe cleaner and used it along with two other iridescent white pipe cleaners.

keywords: Winter winter Christmas art craft decoration creative

overview.Overview: Christmas is around the corner and it's time to decorate! This simple snowman decoration is the perfect family craft activity!

step_1.Step 1: For this activity you will need: pencil, hot glue, scissors, 2 medium button of the same color (any color will do), 3 medium black buttons, a piece of ½ centimeter thick ribbon, and red, blue, green and white foam sheets

step_2.Step 2: Trace two circles on a piece of white foam sheet. Take note that one circle should be bigger than the other.  Cut both traced circles, then glue both circles on a piece of red foam sheet. The two should stick side-by-side to form the whole snowman figure.

step_3.Step 3: Cut the red foam sheet but make sure that you have a small excess border on it. This should highlight the white body of the snowman.

step_4.Step 4: Cut a strip of red foam sheet and glue it on the neck of the snowman, creating a wrapped neck effect. This is his scarf. Glue the three black buttons just below the scarf of the snowman. Add the eyes of the snowman on the head.

step_5.Step 5: Cut and glue a piece of pointed triangle using the green foam sheet. Place it on the center of the face just below the eyes. This is his nose. Add a smile from a piece of green foam sheet. Glue this just below the nose.

step_6.Step 6: Using the light blue foam sheet, cut the hat of the snowman. Cut a strip of green sponge paper and glue it on top of the hat brim. Glue the hat on top of the snowman’s head. Cut a piece of ribbon, then fix it on the top part of the hat, just behind it. Secure it thoroughly using hot glue.

overview.Overview: This spider web fine motor activity is so much fun and an excellent way to develop find motor skills!

step_1.Step 1: For this activity you will need: white yard, plastic spiders, a basket with holes in the sides (e.g. a laundry basket), and clothespins, tweezers, or gator grabbers.

step_2.Step 2: String the yarn back and forth through the holes on the basket. Go in all different directions so that it looks like a spider web. Add the spider rings to the bottom of the basket.

step_3.Step 3: Have the kiddo use the tweezers or clothespins to try to pick up a spider without touching a web.

overview.Overview: This ocean sensory bin is such a fun way for kids to play and learn about the ocean this summer! Kids will have a blast digging in the sand and playing in the water while learning about the ocean habitat.

step_1.Step 1: For this activity you will need: a shallow plastic storage bin, dollar store ocean animal toys, dollar store decorative shells, play sand, water, and blue food coloring.

step_2.Step 2: Pour sand on one side of the bin. Place a bunch of shells at the edge of the sand to act as a barrier between the sand and water.

step_3.Step 3: Slowing pour water in the other side of the bin. It will need to be fairly shallow to keep the water from totally going over into the sand. You can add a few drops of blue food coloring to the water and stir it in with a whisk, if you would like.

step_4.Step 4: Add the ocean animals to the water in the bin.

overview.Overview: Are you stuck inside? Too rainy,too hot, too snowy? Kids still need to get the wiggles out and a stuck indoors day can mean a ton of unused energy. If your kids seem like they are climbing the walls, then try this easy and cheap balloon tennis game. I always make sure I have balloons on hand for indoor gross motor play.

step_1.Step 1: For this activity you will need: balloons and dollar store flyswatters (or paper plates)

overview.Overview: Blast those darn piggies with water balloon Angry Birds! Inspired by the popular video game Angry Birds this takes the game outside into the sun for fun all summer long.

Use painter’s tape to make a web-like design on a doorway opening. Give your kids some newspaper to scrunch up and throw up at the web. Or get creative and use other light-weight objects like balloons. Have them count how many objects stick versus how many don’t for extra learning points.
A simple roll of low-tack Painter’s tape will be your new best friend once you try these genius ideas that get kids exerting their energy in all sorts of creative ways.

Build a masking tape town and keep your children happy and busy for hours! Kids ages 3 and up can design and build this city with nothing more than masking tape, toys cars and people, and a flat surface. This is a great activity to encourage creativity, organization and cooperative play.

This bean bag number toss has all the makings of a perfect preschool activity! It’s simple to set up, easy to play, lots of moving, and learning that can be easily adjusted to be ideal for each little one.

Place a balloon between your child’s knees and have them waddle across the room without dropping it. Make it more challenging for older kids by having them go around a few obstacles. If they drop it, they have to go back to the start.

Get out those plastic red Solo cups and a few ping pong balls (or any small object that will fit in the cup) and have your kids toss the ball to a partner and try and catch it in the cup. Start out close together and then keep taking a step backwards to increase the challenge. For a single-player, they can simply throw the ball in the air and try and catch it.
